comments.commentBody:
OKAY, it is past ten p.m. and now I've printed out Thursday's grid,
so I can comment, for all those Dashing Dans and Donnas who didn't:

Wednesday's 68 ACROSS ("LIRR") is where I get to do the puzzle every day - the dear ol' Long Island Rail Road!

Ahh, feel better now, g'nite!

This one took me much longer than an average Thursday.  I looked for a trick, but didn't get the '--' clue ar all and did everything from crosses where they occurred.  I did it in Across Lite and that may have hurt, but I doubt it.  I won't look down my nose at it, but it bent my mind.  Nice concept and well done.  I winder why I thought Spain was the Hemingway site and Saul was my King.  Nabob's vineyard and Jezebel were just part of the Lectionary on Sunday and I still went with Saul first.  My first thought was there was an Eye, Ear, Nose, Throat rebus in store.  Someone should try that.  I know a doctor.

What if what the General and his aides said was the unvarnished truth about Obama, Biden and the rest of this administration and the French. What does that say about our chances of winning this war, that to me is the the larger question. President Obama needs to address the nation and tell us what the game plan is in Afghanistan. I am not at all encoraged by all this because brave men and women are losing thier lives in this conflict and I am not certain for what.

Americans are weary of the 9 year old war??????

Yes, I am weary. All these political machinations described in this article leave me asking myself "Why bother?" No intruder has won in Afghanistan in 2000 years. Why are we different?

We should concentrate on proper homeland security and energy independence.

here's an interesting quote about the new/old gen in charge now.

WASHINGTON, Sep 12 2007 (IPS) - In sharp contrast to the lionisation of Gen. David Petraeus by members of the U.S. Congress during his testimony this week, Petraeus's superior, Admiral William Fallon, chief of the Central Command (CENTCOM), derided Petraeus as a sycophant during their first meeting in Baghdad last March, according to Pentagon sources familiar with reports of the meeting.

Fallon told Petraeus that he considered him to be "an ass-kissing little chickenshit" and added, "I hate people like that", the sources say. That remark reportedly came after Petraeus began the meeting by making remarks that Fallon interpreted as trying to ingratiate himself with a superior.
This war is an unwinnable boondoggle and no amount of deck chair-rearranging will make it otherwise.

President Obama is wrong to say we must continue this war.  There is a difference between the Taliban and Al Quaeda, and we can chase Al Quaeda (and any terrorists plotting murders) around the world without invading nations.  The population sees us as foreign invaders, trying to spread Christian morals.  There is no chance of convincing them otherwise.  If there are modernizing forces there, we will not get anywhere just by killing religious insurgents.  These people grew up there, and do not want foreigners invading their land.  It's that simple.  We leave, and they lose most of their hatred of us.  I highly doubt that Afghanis will have much drive to attack outside of Afghanistan, or not more than they do currently.  Our leaving will greatly decrease that drive.  We owe it to the living, and to those who died and were maimed in fighting, to end this war already.  We end it, and they will to.  It's as simple as that.  Shalom.

To win the hearts and minds of the Afghans, maybe it might help to put an American of South Asian/Muslim descent? It would make a huge difference since so much of business interactions there are based on informal, handshake type deals. Karzai and co. are BAD NEWS!!! Check their bank accounts in Dubai and the Cayman Islands. I voted for Pres. Obama but I tend to agree more with VP Biden.
War is so twentieth century (BCE).  Let's stop fighting and move on to something constructive.  Wind down the military and wind up humane worldwide development.

Commanders are viewed and eventually judged differently depending on where one sleeps and walks. Alexander Haig was lambasted during the Reagan presidency for his famous, or infamous, statement of "I am in charge here". Later some of my readings about this incident have presented Mr. Haig in a different and more positive light. Maybe he used a poor choice of words; but his intentions were clear and even honorable. Apparently that is still up for debate. Of course in those days, I walked in the safety of a serene college campus and slept peaceably close by in a small off campus apartment. Years before I slept in the mud and walked under the eerie triple canopy jungle near to the Cambodian border. On a few days in late March and early April, 1967 then Lt. Col. Alexander Haig demonstrated not only outstanding personal bravery, but clear and direct decisive military skills that eventually saved many of our fellow soldiers in the midst of a battle that saw our unit outnumbered at least three to one. At the time human wave attacks were then used to describe one night battle. Officers were relieved in our unit in months prior to that event called the battle of Ap Gu. At least one relieved officer was in my opinion dangerously, if not criminally, inept. He was dismissed from our line unit and we all moved on smartly, as it was said in those days. Our President justifiably removed General Mc Chrystal because at this moment young troops are not only sleeping rough, but are in harms way. Besides the grand view of the mission, I trust that our president was also thinking of those who sleep and walk tonight in very different places than television pundits, political advisors and indeed than four star generals. God speed to our president.

President Obama needs to clean house of all Bush/Cheney holdovers! I could just imagine General MacChristal & Bush sharing a beer and some sophmoric tale, both in detention more than out in school, lack of respect for authority that they wore as a badge of honor, ranked 200+ out of 800+ in class standing. The general's wife stated that his personality hadn't changed since the day they met! Really.

In order for COIN doctrine to succeed, we are told that it is imperative to 'win the hearts and minds' of the local population.

What COINdinistas don't tell us is that before we can even think about winning over foreign populations, we must win the 'hearts and minds' back home. That is, if we don't have full - and I mean *full* - civilian, political, economic and domestic support, our COIN forces will have already lost 3/4 the battle.

And even if you have full support, I personally think that a counter-insurgency undertaken is a counter-insurgency lost.

Wars are unwinnable. Do I need to go into the specifics?

Guerrilla warfare. IEDS. Stretched supply lines. Capital-intensive vs. labor-intensive. Lack of will. Nationalism. Corruption. Conscripts. Economies. Etc. etc. etc..

Can we please deal with an educated reality?

After hearing all the negative comments about Obama and how he leads, he showed today he IS a leader and a very effective one too. He has taken alot of flack about what kind of President he is and I hope this quiets down all the negative talk about him.

I agree that McChrystal was "stupid" to use Rolling Stone as a forum for his poorly-formed attitudes. What I don't agree with, is the idea that Obama has intelligently prosecuted the war in Afghanistan. Rules of Engagement that place our soldiers' lives in jeopardy to score meaningless political points, procrastinating for months before agreeing to increase troop levels below the number identified as meaningful, using a layer of "expert" apparatchiks to control(hinder) our actions...all this and more fed the poison ejected by McChrystal and his cohort.

This Hamlet streak of Obama's marks all his crisis responses, from Jobs to the Gulf spill to the (unacknowledged) "War on Terror". With our announced Summer 2111 withdrawal, there is no compelling urge for headlong confrontation by the Afghan Taliban, or support by Karzai's corrupt minions.
Meanwhile, American casualties will continue to mount in a war that is racing to its arbitrary, meaningless conclusion.
Richard Holbrooke says; and he's right that there is no winning in Afghanistan if we do not address Waziristan!
Anyone who would voluntarily take the managing job in Baltimore can only be described as certifiable.
OMG!!! Donovan speaks Spanish?!  NOW I am impressed!

If more people were like this gentle giant in professional sports there would be much more positive attention given to athletes. It is just a shame that it takes his death for people to realize what he dedicated his life to.

You bring up a very key point. If more celebrities used their elevated status to promote change and humanitarian work, much more could be accomplished around the world. It is a sad reality that we as Americans focus on so many of the deplorable actions of athletes and other celebrities without giving more attention to the ones who make a difference. We can only hope that people can and will be inspired by Bol's story.

No video replays. It is a beautiful and simple game. It is also an international game played in the poorest and richest countries. Games sanctioned by FIFA need to be played under similar conditions. You absolutely cannot have games with expensive tech used in some leagues and not in others. Widen your perspectives!
Donovan is my heroe, now lets beat  ghana .
to karen...not even a colonel of truth?
gotta go with the flow here.  dempsey was marvelous, a terrifying threat all day, as my mexican mate said, "dempsey, that guy's a savage!"
Didn't the Taliban lithium?
